Author: Deleted User#0000
Content:
About the hidden stuff. As I said to @KomodoWorld i believe that we should try to include in native mode any specific functionnality that could be needed. Just an example : 
Imagine it is run by a company. On its current state I think it s a requirement. The company won t take risks for free. So that means they should be able to "puncture" by a specific amount / percentage. All this stuff natively included and modifiable via a specific parameter table / whatever. That could even allow special event like : today swapping is free. Or just for a coin is without fee. 

Including this type of logic seems best done during inception than afterwards.


Another thing I will include is the ability for any side to choose to do only z tx for compatible chains. Basically just a checkbox will make it very easy.

This indeed seems like a good idea but in that case it could make things harder hw side. So including a potential additional fee maybe is useful.

Maybe this stuff will never be used : i mean the fee side... but if it s handled by default... it s better ^^

Content: Cool @Deleted User yeah, I was planning to have a beta environment and another for production. I can deploy to a free plan in zeit.co or heroku for the moment (or the starter plan in digitalocean). But usually deploying to a new provider requires some tweaks, so it would be nice to do it only once. About requirements we need a server with ssh access, where we can run nodejs and mysql. We'll need to be able to request two port numbers (for frontend and backend) and to assign domain names and paths to those ports

Author: Deleted User#0000
Content:
and tbh this made me realize that maybe a change in infrastructure may be needed, on a more scalable way, let me explain : 

As of today, we'll rely on 4 main components : 

UI 
Payment processor
DB
Coin Server

At this stage PP and Coin server are on the same machine, but tweaking it for any coin to be redirected to the proper server may allow this solution to scale : Imagine server A can't handle more coins : just add a new one (B) with fresh coins to add, and just a param in db allowing the main PP server to point at targetted nodes may be more efficient

Author: Deleted User#0000
Content: No limitation whatever coin we need to add afterwards

Author: Deleted User#0000
Content: Even if eth not included at start. Make it possible really easily really fast without struggling is my goal :p.

Author: maxijb#2198
Content: So, I've been thinking about the hardware requirements... we'll need to run 2 nodeJS processes, so that should require  2 cores, plus mysql  that will do all the heavy work, so maybe 4 cores are a reasonable setup

Author: maxijb#2198
Content: About memory , a nodeJS app has a limit of 1.8gb of ram, that times 2 is 3.6 gb, plus mysql... I think we could be ok with 4GB of ram to start

Author: maxijb#2198
Content: Disk space, the biggest chunk  will be ocupied by the database... how much can that grow depends on how much traffic we'll get... let's say we start with 2GB?  Plus a 100 or 200mb of logs... then the source code will not take much space... probably 8 GB will be more than enough

Author: maxijb#2198
Content: Of course, the test environment will require much less equipment, probably we can live with 2 cores, 2gb memory, 2gb space

Author: maxijb#2198
Content: And the way that nodejs applications scale -as they are single threaded- is by adding more instances, so let's say than one node can handle 10k concurrent users (this is a benchmark that I saw online but we'll need to measure it on our app to have a clear picture), we should monitor our cpu usage and whenever that's consistently high, we could add more cores, and run more instances on those new CPUs

Author: maxijb#2198
Content: That's a conservative estimation I can make a priori, we'll know better once we start serving requests of course... not sure how easy it is to scale hardware in your infrastructure?
